name: Abrasion Resistance
description: The resistance of a paper or paperboard surface to being worn down, roughened, and disrupted by sliding frictional contact with other substances, as measured by weight loss of a weighed test sample.

name: Absorbency
description: The ability of paper to absorb fluids such as water or printing ink.

name: Accelerated Aging
description: A method of predicting the long-term aging characteristics of paper by exposing it to an elevated temperature and controlled environment of dry or moist heat for a specified time and then measuring its strength loss.

name: Acid-Free Paper
description: A paper having no acidity and no residual acid-producing chemicals. Acid-free papers may also be slightly alkaline to resist the harmful effects of an acidic environment and provide greater longevity.

name: Acidification
description: Decrease in the pH of soil and water due to precipitation containing dissolved ammonium compounds, sulphur and nitrogen oxides; an indirect cause of forest damage.

name: Activated Sludge Treatment
description: A biological method of cleaning up waste waters in three stages. Stage I involves (anaerobic) equilibration. In stage II activated sludge containing micro-organisms is led into an aeration basin to speed up oxidation of organic matter and ammonia. In stage III the sludge is allowed to settle and the treated waste water is run off. Some sludge is removed and a portion is returned to the aeration basin.

name: Adhesive Paper
description: Paper that has an adhesive substance applied to one side, which when dampened adheres to the surface it is pressed against.

name: Aerated Lagoon
description: A biological waste water treatment method in which air (oxygen) fed into an aeration basin reduces the effluent load.

name: Air Dying
description: Method of drying the paper web on the paper machine by blowing air along the direction of the web.

name: Air Mail Paper
description: Light weight, thin and mainly woodfree writing papers for air mail. Anaerobic treatment Process employing micro–organisms to reduce organic matter in waste water in the absence of oxygen.

name: AOX (Absorbable Organohalogens)
description: Absorbable organic halogens. AOX is a sum parameter measuring total concentration of chlorine bound to organic compounds in waste water. AOX measures all chlorine compounds both harmful and harmless (a sum parameter).

name: Appearance Properties
description: Paper properties including its whiteness, brightness, colour, gloss and opacity.

name: Art Paper
description: High quality and rather heavy two-side coated printing paper with smooth surface. The reproduction of fine screen single-and multicolour pictures ("art on paper") requires a paper that has an even, well closed surface and a uniform ink absorption.

name: Artificial Parchment
description: Woodfree paper that is produced by fine and extended grinding of certain chemical pulps and/or the admixture of special additives. As a result of the "smeary" grinding, the fibre structure closes homogeneously. It is used e.g. for wrapping meat and sausages or as corrugating medium for biscuit packaging.

name: Auxiliary Chemical
description: A chemical added to a stage of paper–making aimed at improving the efficiency of a part of the process.

name: Back-Pressure Power
description: Generation of both heat and electricity from fuel; gives greater efficiency than condensing power.

name: Bale
description: Solid, compressed stack of pulp or paper sheets.

name: Banknote Paper
description: Highly resistant, age-resistant, suitable for 4-colour printing, with watermark and other falsification safeguards such as embedded metal strip. Often containing cotton fibres (See "Rag paper").

name: Basis Weight
description: The weight in grams per sheet of paper cut to its basic size in square metres.

name: Bast
description: Fibres located in the inner bark layer of trees and in outer portions of other fibrous, woody plants.

name: Beatability
description: The ease with which pulp can be beaten to achieve the desired properties.

name: Beating
description: Mechanical treatment of fibres to improve fibre bonding.

name: Bible Paper
description: Thin, high quality printing paper, with an average grammage of 30 gsm, but wich be as high ad 40/50 gsm, and which has a fairly high density. It is a woodfree, bleached fibre paper, and the better grades contain rag. It needs to be strong, to be a particularly resistant to tears and creasing, and it must have a closed structure. Usually very opaque, the presence of gar and a high percentage of fillers with strong covering power, primarily titanium dioxide, help to improve its printing properties.

name: Biological Waste Water Treatment
description: A method of cleaning up waste water using living micro–organisms such as bacteria. See: Activated sludge treatment, Aerated lagoon, Anaerobic process.

name: Biosludge
description: Sludge formed (in the aeration basin) during biological waste water treatment or other biological treatment process.

name: Black Liquor
description: Mixture of cooking chemicals and dissolved wood material remaining after sulphate cooking; recovered during pulp washing, concentrated by evaporation and burned in the recovery boiler to regenerate the cooking chemicals and generate energy.

name: Bleach Plant
description: Department of a pulp mill where pulp is bleached.

name: Bleached Lined Folding Boxboard
description: Bleached lined folding boxboard is a multi–layer paperboard that has a bleached woodfree liner on one or both sides. Between two liners there are intermediate layers and middle layers of mechanical or waste paper pulp.

name: Bleached Pulp
description: Pulp whose natural brightness has been improved using chemicals.

name: Bleaching
description: A chemical treatment used to whiten, brighten and improve the performance of pulp (the lignin in the wood is oxidised).

name: Blister
description: Oval, sharply defined, bubblelike formation that bulges out on both sides of the web. Such bubbles occur during the heatset drying of coated papers.

name: Blotting Paper
description: Bulky, highly absorbent, filler–free paper which is mostly produced from pure cotton in the form of bleached linters and from chemical pulp.

name: Board
description: Paper product with grammage in excess of 400 gsm, made in several layers and laminated when wet or sometimes stuck together with adhesives (casein, starch paste, animal glue, etc.). In some types the different layers have the same fibre composition, whilst in other the outer layer (the cover) is made from better quality materials to improve its surface qualities.

name: Bonding Strength
description: Amount of resistance to the forces of picking, splitting, delamination, and splitting of ink films during printing.

name: Bond Paper
description: A writing paper, originally used for printing stocks and bonds, now used for letterheads, stationery and forms.

name: Book Paper
description: A paper designed and normally used primarily for printing by one or more of various printing processes.

name: Brightening
description: Addition of optical brighteners to the stock to make the pulp/paper appear whiter.

name: Brightness
description: A measure of the whiteness of pulp and paper. Percent of reflectance at a standard wavelength.

name: Bristol
description: A heavyweight paper, usually 6 points or more in thickness, used for printing, filing and index systems, and mailing cards.

name: Broke
description: This term is applied to the waste generated during the various production processes, from books, magazines, used packaging, as well as the waste and trim generated by the papermaking process itself. It may be blank or printed. In the latter case, it has to be de–inked if it is to be used for the production of "fine" paper.

name: Brush Glazing
description: Glazing of coated paper with the aid of brushes.

name: Bulk
description: The thickness of a number of sheets of paper or of a number of pages.

name: Bulk Product
description: A mass–produced product sold in large volumes without individual specifications, usually in compliance with a standard. For example newsprint.

name: Burst Strength
description: The resistance of paper or paperboard to rupture as measured by the hydrostatic pressure required to burst it when a uniformly distributed and increasing pressure is applied to one of its sides.

name: Calcium Carbonate
description: Used in papermaking as a filler or coating pigment.

name: Calendered Paper
description: Paper that has been calendered in order to obtain a smoother, more glossy surface than originally.

name: Calendering
description: Mechanical treatment applied to paper to make it smoother and glossy. The smoothness is achieved by means of pressure, whilst the gloss is achieved by friction. As a result of the compression, calendering always reduces the thickness, the porosity, the compressibility, the opacity and the whiteness of the paper. These side effects are often undesired in the case of printing papers. Calendaring, on the other hand, has a little impact on the strength of the paper.

name: Caliper
description: The thickness of a single sheet of paper, usually measured in nanometers.

name: Capacitor Paper
description: See "Electrical insulating paper".

name: Capacity Utilisation Rate
description: Indicates the efficiency (%) at which a mill or machine is operating.

name: Carbon Dioxide (CO²)
description: Produced by burning coal and other carbon containing products. Burning fossil fuels or wood based products raises atmospheric carbon dioxide levels.

name: Carbon Paper
description: Carbon paper is a thin paper with a waxy coating, that is used to produce carbon copies on typewriters or other office equipment. Carbon base paper is made from chemical pulp.

name: Carbonless Copy Paper
description: Paper that permits making multiple copies without intervening layers of carbon paper. The paper translates pressure into a dye reaction which transfers the image to the copy. Carbonless copy papers are mainly used for continuous form sets, for covered pay slips, for vouchers to be dispatched by post and for payment forms. In the US and some other countries, carbonless copy paper is also called NCR paper (= Non Carbon Required).

name: Cardboard
description: Paper product with grammages of between 151 and 400 gsm. Cardboard may comprise a single layer or several pies, stuck together when wet or with glue. It is produced with better quality raw materials than board. There are great variety of cardboards, which differ widely in their fibre composition, surface treatments and uses.

name: Cast-Coated Paper
description: Cast–coated papers are coated papers that have obtained their high gloss by moulding on a highly polished, chromium plated drying cylinder.

name: Causticizing
description: Process by which green liquor from sulphate pulping is converted to white liquor, thus allowing the cooking chemicals to be reused.

name: Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD)
description: The amount of oxygen consumed in complete chemical oxidation of matter present in waste water; indicates the content of slowly degradable organic matter present.

name: Chemical Pulp
description: Carboydrate polymer of plant origin that is the main component of the fibrous parts of plants. Various grades that differ in their separation methods and in the grade of wood used as the source are available for use in the paper industry. The paper products that can be produced vary with the grade of cellulose.

name: Chemicals Recovery
description: In chemical pulping, the recovery, treatment and regeneration of cooking chemicals.

name: Chemi-Thermomechanical Pulp (CTMP)
description: Chemi–mechanical pulp produced by treating wood chips with chemicals (usually sodium sulphite) and steam before mechanical defibration.

name: China Clay
description: Mineral (kaolin) used in papermaking as both filler and coating pigment.

name: Chipboard/Grey Board
description: Paperboard made from waste paper pulp, rough or machine glazed, also lined on one or two sides or unlined.

name: Cigarette Paper
description: This light weight, unsized paper (grammage 18 to 24g), converted to improve glowing. It normally has a filler content of approx. 30%.

name: Clarification
description: Separation of a solid component from a solution.

name: Clarifier
description: Basin where sludge is removed from treated effluent by settling; see Activated sludge treatment.

name: Coating Colour Kitchen
description: Department where coating colour is prepared and mixed.

name: Combined Deinking
description: Deinking process combining flotation and washing; cf. flotation deinking, washing deinking.

name: Coated One-Side Label
description: A coated one-side paper designed specifically for the requirements of label paper, including those for printing, varnishing, lacquering, bronzing, die-cutting and the labeling application.

name: Coated Paper
description: Paper with one of more layers of coating (pigments and adhesives applied to one or both surfaces of the sheet during the coating process). Coatings are applied to confer particular characteristics, especially printablity. The choice of components determines the degree of smoothness, gloss, opacity, printability and colour yield of the inks.

name: Coating
description: Paste of pigments and adhesives applied to one or both sides of the sheet during the coating process. The choice of pigments used determines the smoothness, gloss, opacity, printability and chromatic yield of the printing inks.

name: COBB SIZE TEST
description: A method of measuring the degree of sizing of paper or paperboard by the weight of water absorbed under prescribed conditions during a specified time.

name: CONDENSING POWER
description: Power generation in which fuel is burned for electricity production only.

name: CONSISTENCY
description: Dry solids content (%) of pulp present in a pulp slurry.

name: CONVERTING
description: The operation of treating, modifying, or otherwise manipulating the finished paper and paperboard so that it can be made into end–user products.

name: COPYING PAPER
description: Copying paper is an uncoated paper in woodfree or mechanical grades, white or coloured in A4 and A3.

name: CORE
description: The tube, usually made of paperboard, on which a paper roll is wound.

name: CORRUGATING MEDIUM
description: Bands of relatively uniform width that extend around a roll parallel to the machine direction and within which are diagonal markings resembling a rope or tire-like pattern. Papers used as fluting for the production of corrugated board.

name: CORRUGATED BOARD
description: Corrugated board is a material made up 2/3 layers of paper (flat sheet) that are stuck to other, fluted sheet. Such a structure offers specific strength and rigidity based on the layers that are joined together. There are three grades of corrugated: deep flutes (producing a board with a thickness in excess of 4.5 mm), medium flutes (from 5.5 to 4.4 mm) micro–flutes (with a thickness less than 2.5 mm).

name: CRITICAL LOAD
description: Highest pollutant load that, in the long term, does not damage essential characteristics in an ecosystem.

name: CROSS-MACHINE DIRECTION
description: A direction perpendicular to the direction of web travel through the paper machine.

name: CTMP
description: See chemi–thermomechanical pulp.

name: CUT-SIZE PAPER
description: Paper used for printing, copying, or duplicating in small sizes and generally up to and including 11 x 17 in.

name: CWF (COATED WOODFREE)
description: Coated woodfree paper made from pure chemical pulp, available in various sizes or on reels.

name: DANDY ROLL
description: A cylinder on a paper machine used to improve formation; also wire roll.

name: DECOR PAPER
description: Woodfree, white or single-colour paper, often printed with various patterns, e.g. wood grains. The final product consists of laminated boards or directly coated particle boards used for furniture production.

name: DECKLE
description: A term sometimes used to refer to the width or trim of a paper machine.

name: DEFIBRATION
description: Separation of wood fibres by mechanical and/or chemical means.

name: DEINKABILITY
description: Suitability of recovered paper for deinking; depends on paper grade, printing process used, age of paper, and other factors.

name: DEINKED PULP (DIP)
description: Paper pulp produced by deinking of recovered paper.

name: DEINKING
description: Removal of printing ink and impurities from recovered paper; to produce recycled fibre pulp with maximum whiteness and purity.

name: DEINKING LOSS
description: Unwanted loss of solid material from pulp during deinking (usually 10-40%).

name: DELIGNIFICATION
description: The removal of lignin, the material that binds wood fibres together, during the chemical pulping process.

name: DEPOSIT
description: Mass of airborne pollutants deposited on a unit area of land or water in a given time, e.g. grams per square metre per year (g/m²/a).

name: DERESINATION
description: Reducing the resin (pitch) content of wood prior to cooking either by storage or using bleaching chemicals to reduce the resin content in pulp.

name: DIGESTER HOUSE
description: That part of a chemical pulp mill where cooking takes place.

name: DIGITAL PRINTING
description: Printing system that cuts out the intermediate stages between prepress (creation of text and images on the computer) and printing. It eliminates the preparation of printings elements, make ready times and the start-up procedure required for conventional presses. In addition, presses are only capable of printing the physical image borne by their printings elements, which is identical for the every impression. Digital presses can be personalized for each single run.

name: DIRECT COOKING
description: Cooking in which heating is achieved by blowing steam into the cooking liquor.

name: DISPERSION
description: The separation of a substance into the smallest possible particles using another substance (the medium). Used in papermaking to homogenize pulp properties and remove impurities.

name: DISSOLVING PULP
description: A chemical pulp grade used, for example, in the production of acetate and viscose fibres and cellulose films.

name: DOCUMENT PAPER
description: Document paper is paper with a high ageing resistance. It is woodfree but may also contain rags or be fully made from rags and is used for documents that have to be preserved for a longer period.

name: DOUBLE COATING
description: Coating of paper or board twice on one or both sides.

name: DRAINAGE
description: Formation of a paper or board web on the wire by removing water at the paper machine wet end.

name: DRAWING PAPER
description: General term for paper intended to be used for drawing. The quality of normal drawing paper varies greatly, depending upon the intended use. It is almost never contains wood pulp, whilst the finer grades that are intended to be kept for long periods contain a high percentage of rag or are entirely rag papers. The stock is always well sized in order to resist penetration by water–colours. It may often also be sized with starch or animal size and the surface is, to a greater or lesser degree, rough. The best grades are part hand, part machine made on cylinder machines, whilst medium and cheap grades are produced on Fourdrinier machines. Only very high quality paper is made by hand. Grammages ranges from 100 to 400 gsm. Given the intended use, these papers are never watermarked other than with the manufacturer’s mark. Ingres paper is a high quality drawing paper. This is a laid paper made by hand or partly by hand partly by machine. With a coarse, distinctive grain, a grammage of 90–100 gsm and is often in pastel shades. Technical drawing paper, also referred to as tracing paper, is a dense, highly transparent paper with grammages ranging from 30 to 100 gsm.

name: DRY COATING
description: Coating method in which a binder is applied to the paper surface followed by dry coating pigment.

name: DRY CREPING
description: Creping of a dry paper web.

name: DRY END
description: Final part of the paper machine from the drying section onwards.

name: DRY SOLIDS
description: Mass of dried sample as a percentage of mass of original sample.

name: DRY STRENGTH
description: Mechanical strength of a dry paper sheet (includes tensile strength, tearing resistance and folding endurance).

name: DUPLEX BOARD
description: Duplex board consists of two layers, mostly made from waste paper pulp. It is used for packaging purposes.

name: ELASTIC STRENGTH
description: The ability of paper or board to resist stress acting in the plane of the sample.

name: ELECTRICAL INSULATING PAPER
description: Strong, pore–free paper, sometimes impregnated with synthetic resins, made from chemical pulp. Electrical insulating paper must neither contain fillers nor conductive contaminants (metals, coal, etc.) nor salts or acids. Cable papers, that are wound around line wires in a spiral-like fashion, are electrical insulating papers with a particularly high strength in machine direction. Electrical insulating papers also include electrolytic papers and capacitor paper.

name: ELECTROSTATIC PRECIPITATOR
description: Used to clean up flue and process gases. Removes 99.5–99.8% of dust particles emitted from recovery boilers, lime kilns and bark–fired boilers.

name: EMULSION COATING
description: Coating of paper with an emulsion containing plastic or resin.

name: EMBOSSING
description: Raised, heavily printed areas in a press sheet due to a deformation of the paper from the tack of the ink film and blanket.

name: ENVELOPE PAPER
description: Envelope paper can be woodfree or wood–containing, machine glazed or calendered, white or in colour and is used for envelopes. It must be opaque, writable, and printable and must have a high folding strength.

name: ENZYME BLEACHING
description: Bleaching technique in which cooked and oxygen–delignified chemical pulp is treated with enzymes prior to final bleaching. Allows pulp to be bleached without chlorine chemicals.

name: EVAPORATION PLANT
description: Unit used at pulp mills to concentrate spent liquor to make it suitable for burning and chemicals recovery.

name: EXTENDED COOKING
description: Method of cooking pulp to low lignin content, thereby reducing the need for bleaching chemicals.

name: FASTNESS
description: Resistance to colour fading

name: FCO PAPER
description: Film coated paper where the coating is applied with two rollers.

name: FLIMSY
description: Paper which was long used for making carbon copies of letters either by pressing or by using carbon paper on a typewriter. Nowadays, those thin sheets of paper have disappeared from the shelves of retailers, as they have been replaced by photocopiers.

name: FIBRE LOSS
description: Loss of fibre material in pulp and paper processing.

name: FIBREBOARD
description: Board made from defibrated wood chips, used as a building board.

name: FIBRILLATION
description: A structural change occurring in the walls of chemical pulp fibres during beating.

name: FILLER
description: Pigment, added to papermaking stock to improve properties such as opacity and smoothness, and often to reduce cost.

name: FILLER CONTENT
description: Percentage of filler in a paper.

name: FILTER PAPER
description: Unsized paper made from chemical pulp, in some cases also with an admixture of rags, sometimes with a wet strength finish. Filtration rate and selectivity, which are both dependent on the number and the size of the pores, can be controlled by specific grinding of the pulps and creping.

name: FINE PAPER
description: High–quality printing, writing or copy paper produced from chemical pulp and usually containing less than 10% mechanical pulp.

name: FINE PAPER
description: Quality term for a large number of woodfree printing papers, based on chemical pulp with usually less than 10 % mechanical pulp. Sometimes fine paper also is made with an admixture of rags or wholly from rag pulp.

name: FLAME RESISTANT PAPER
description: Flame resistant paper may ignite but must extinguish immediately so that it chars. This property is imparted to the paper by impregnation with certain chemicals.

name: FLEXOGRAPHIC PRINTING
description: A method of relief letterpress printing using flexible rubber or photopolymer plates on wet rotary presses.

name: FLONG PAPER
description: A pulp–like, coated–type paper.

name: FLOTATION DEINKING
description: Deinking process in which air is blown into a dilute fibre suspension. Ink particles adhere to the air bubbles and rise to the surface, where they are removed.

name: FLUE GAS SCRUBBER
description: Equipment for removing impurities from flue gases by dissolving them in aqueous solution.

name: FLUFF
description: Loose fibers projecting from a paper's surface.

name: FLUFFING
description: The removal of fibrous materials from a paper’s surface during printing.

name: FODDER PULP
description: Protein produced from pulp mill spent liquors and sometimes mixed with animal feeds.

name: FOLDING BOXBOARD
description: Single or multilayer paperboard made from primary and/or secondary fibres, sometimes with a coated front, used to make consumer packaging (cartons).

name: FOLDING ENDURANCE
description: The number of double folds a paper will withstand under tension and specified conditions before it breaks at the fold line.

name: FORMATION
description: Refers to the uniformity or lack of it in the distribution of the fibers when manufacturing paper; can be observed by looking through the sheet; a good formation is uniform or "Close", while a poor formation is not.

name: FOUR-SIDED TRIM (TRIM 4)
description: After the job is printed and folded, a trim will be taken off all four sides to remove any reference or registration marks and give a clean edge to the pile of sheets.

name: FOURDRINIER WIRE
description: Horizontally moving metal or plastic mesh belt (wire) on which the paper web is formed.

name: FREE SHEET
description: A paper that does not contain groundwood or mechanical pulp.

name: FSC - FOREST STEWARDSHIP COUNCIL
description: An independent, international, environmentally and socially oriented forest certification organization. It trains, accredits and monitors third-party certifiers around the world and works to establish international forest management standards. Environment Paper has four colors that are FSC certified.

name: FULLY BLEACHED PULP
description: Pulp that has been bleached to the highest brightness attainable (> 90 ISO).

name: GLOSS
description: An extra quantity of varnish, which gives a glossy appearance when dry.

name: GRADE
description: The classification given to paper due to its unique characteristics, which includes brightness, opacity, content.

name: GRAIN DIRECTION
description: The direction of the fibers in paper.

name: GRAIN LONG
description: Term used to designate that the grain of the paper is parallel to the longest measurement of a sheet of paper. The fibers are aligned parallel to the length of the sheet.

name: GRAIN SHORT
description: Opposite of grain long. Grain of the paper runs at the right angles to the longest dimension of the sheet. Fiber alignment in grain short paper parallels the sheet? Shortest dimension.

name: GRAMMAGE
description: The basis weight of paper stated in metric terms of grams per square meter and expressed as g/m2. To convert from basis weight to grams per square meter (g/m2), multiply basis weight by 1406.5 (a constant factor) and divide by the number of square inches in base sheet.

name: GUILLOTINE
description: Device that is used to cut or trim stacks of paper to the desired size.

name: GUMMING
description: In platemaking, the process of applying a thin coating of gum to the non-printing areas of a lithographic plate.

name: HIGH BULK
description: A paper (normally book paper) specifically manufactured to retain a thickness not found in papers of the same basis weight. Frequently used to give thickness to a book with minimal amount of pages.

name: HUMIDIFICATION
description: The addition of moisture to the air.

name: HUMIDITY
description: Moisture condition of the air. Relative humidity is the percent of moisture relative to the actual amount which air at any given temperature can retain without precipitation.

name: HYDRATION
description: A papermaking process that involves beating the pulp so as to increase its ability to hold water and produce a paper with the proper moisture content.

name: INK ABSORPTION
description: The degree with which paper will absorb ink.

name: INK-IN-WATER EMULSION
description: An emulsion of ink and water in which the ink is broken up into fine droplets surrounded by water.

name: INK RECEPTIVITY
description: The ability of a paper surface to accept ink uniformly and adequately from the plate or blanket during printing

name: INK RUB RESISTANCE
description: The resistance of an ink film to scuffing or rubbing on paper or paperboard and as measured by abrasion or rub testing equipment.

name: INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS ORGANIZATIONS (ISO)
description: An organization for the coordinating and establishment of uniform, internationally accepted standards.

name: IVORY BOARD
description: High quality board made in white or colours with a bright clear appearance, particularly used for visiting cards and similar high quality printed work.

name: JOINT
description: The flexible hinge where the cover of a casebound book meets the spine, the permitting the cover to open without breaking the spine of the book or breaking apart the signatures.

name: KRAFT PAPER
description: A strong paper made from sulfate pulp, used for paper products like wrapping, bags and envelopes.

name: LIGHTWEIGHT COATED (LWC)
description: Coated paper whose basis weight is below 60gsm.

name: LONG GRAIN SHEET
description: A sheet whose longer dimension parallels the grain direction.

name: LOW BULK
description: Refers to papers somewhat thinner than the usual papers of the same weight, having a smooth surface, and which is a “thin” sheet.

name: MACHINE DIRECTION
description: The direction in which the fibers flow to the paper machine; the direction of web travel through the paper machine.

name: MACHINE FINISH
description: A smooth finish obtained with calendaring, produced on the paper machine. Often, expressed as M.F.

name: MACHINE GLAZED
description: Having a highly polished finish applied to one side of the paper when it dries against the polished surface of the large-diameter cylinder of the paper machine.

name: MAKING ORDER
description: An order for items not stocked and made up in accordance with the specifications of the purchaser.

name: MATT PAPER
description: A coated paper having a dull smooth surface, reflecting most of the incident light in all directions.

name: MECHANICAL PULP
description: Pulp produced using a non-chemical process and by mechanical treatment. Papers made from mechanical pulp often have good opacity and bulk but yellow more quickly than paper produced from chemically made pulp. Newspapers are often printed on papers having a proportion of mechanical pulp.

name: MILL BRAND
description: A brand name given by the manufacturer for its paper product.

name: MOISTURE CONTENT
description: The amount of moisture contained by paper, expressed as a percentage of its total weight.

name: NAP
description: A slight surface texture of some writing surfaces.

name: NASTA
description: National Association of State Textbook Administrators, an organization that establishes specifications for all material used to manufacture elementary and high school textbooks.

name: NEWSPRINT
description: A generic term used to describe paper of the type used to print newspapers, usually of very high groundwood content.

name: NINEPOINT
description: Paperboards used as the fluted component in the manufacturing of multi-ply combined board or wrapping.

name: NIP
description: The point of contact between two rolls, as in a calendering operation.

name: NLT
description: No less than - relating to quantity information for trade tolerances.

name: NMT
description: No more than - relating to quantity information for trade tolerances.

name: NOMINAL WEIGHT
description: The basis weight used when ordering paper. In manufacturing the basis weight used as a target, allowing for normal manufacturing tolerances, usually of plus or minus 5%. The weight stated as the basis or substance weight of paper; accepted trade tolerance, necessary because of variables in manufacturing paper, is plus (+) or minus (-) 5% of nominal weight.

name: NONRETURNABLE CORE
description: A core, usually of fiber, which is normally used only once.

name: NONWOVEN FABRIC
description: Cloth-like material made from long natural and synthetic fibers formed from a slurry on a wire screen or by laying on a fine mesh screen from an air suspension.

name: NWR
description: Term used to identify narrow width rolls usually under 17 inches.

name: OCR
description: Abbreviation for "Optical Character Recognition"; human readable images which are optically scanned (read) by data and word processing machines.

name: OCR PAPER
description: Paper made for the specific needs of optical character recognition equipment.

name: OFF-MACHINE COATING
description: Indicates the process of applying coating material that is not performed on the paper machine, but as a separate operation.

name: OFF-SET
description: See set-off.

name: OFFSET
description: The most commonly used indirect printing method, in which an impression of type or a design on a flat plate is printed on a cylinder from which it is impressed upon the surface to be printed. Short for offset lithography, but see offset printing.

name: OFFSET CORE
description: A core that is not evenly aligned with the edge of the roll.

name: OFFSET LITHOGRAPHY
description: Offset printing has become the commonly used name for this type of planographic printing; also called lithographic or stone printing. The method of printing using a plate in a single plane, where the non- image area is distinguished from the image area by creating water receptive and non-water receptive areas on the plate. Today, this is generally accomplished on metal surfaces, by either light sensitive coatings or electronic methods.

name: OFFSET PAPER
description: A printing paper, uncoated or coated made for the requirements of offset printing. See book papers.

name: OFFSET PRINTING
description: Also known as indirect printing. The method by which the printing plate is removed from the point of transfer of the printing ink to the paper to be printed, generally by means of a resilient blanket or roll; the resilient blanket or roll actually makes the impression on the paper, thus "offsets" the ink. Unless stated otherwise, can also be specific to the offset lithography or planographic printing process, using a resilient blanket to minimize wear on the plate by the paper being printed.

name: OFFSET WINDING
description: Also called staggered winding; frequent or abrupt off-sets on the end of a roll.

name: OLEOPHILIC
description: Describes the surface of a material that is easily coated by and is compatible with an organic oil; for the opposite see oleophobic. In offset lithography, the image areas of the plate are very oil receptive or oleophilic.

name: OLEOPHOBIC
description: Describes the surface of a material that is not easily coated by and actually repels an organic, non-polar oil; for the opposite see oleophilic. In offset lithography, the non-image areas of the plate have been wet with a water based fountain solution and do not accept the oil based ink and these non-image areas are said to be oleophobic.

name: ONIONSKIN
description: A thin, lightweight paper used primarily for typewritten correspondence.

name: OPACITY
description: Property of paper which obstructs the passage of light and show-through of printing. The characteristic of paper to block the transmission of light, or the ability to provide (low opacity, like tracing paper) or prevent (high opacity) "show through" of dark printing; the human eye is good at comparing this property, but it can be measured by instrument, and is expressed as a percentage of the light that can not pass through the sheet of paper, i.e., a 98% opacity means that 98% of the light can not pass through the sheet, and is absorbed in or reflected from the incident surface.

name: OPAQUE INK
description: An ink that does not allow light to pass through it and "hides" the paper or previous printing under it; normally not used in multicolor process printing, where transparent inks are required. See process inks.

name: OPAQUES
description: Papers that have been opacified to achieve a high level of opacity and a minimum amount of show-through.

name: OPAS
description: An abbreviation for "On/Off Press Application System," a business unit of the Mead Corporation's Fine Paper Division; it is a patented system and materials which allows printers and converters to produce their own carbonless paper on site, either prior to or during the printing of multiple part or ply business forms.

name: OPTICAL BRIGHTENERS
description: See fluorescent dyes.

name: OPTICAL DENSITY
description: The intensity of the color or printed image, usually (but not always) referenced to black and/or white.

name: ORANGE PEEL
description: A granular or pebble-like textured appearance (like an orange peel) that appears as a defect on the surface of a coated or printed paper.

name: OSHA
description: An abbreviation for "Occupational Safety and Health Act" and is a U.S. federal act, with an agency responsible for establishing and enforcing the health and safety standards for all employees of business.

name: OUT-OF-SQUARE
description: Sheet paper which is cut or trimmed with other than 90 degree corners, or that is cut non-parallel or not at right angles to the grain of the paper (cut on the bias).

name: OUTTURN SAMPLE
description: A representative sample taken from a run of paper or a specified shipment.

name: OVEN-DRY (OD)
description: Moisture-free (also bone dry) conditions of pulp and paper. Usually determined by drying a known sample to a constant weight in a completely dry atmosphere at a specified temperature.

name: OVERCOATING
description: See varnish.

name: OVER-PRINT
description: See desensitize (of CF carbonless papers).

name: OVERRUN
description: A quantity of paper made in excess of the amount ordered. Trade customs allow for a certain tolerance for overruns and underruns. A quantity of paper made in excess of the amount ordered; trade practices permit a certain tolerance for overruns and underruns, with the percentage usually dependent upon the size of the order. Also, in printing, copies printed in excess of the quantity ordered.

name: PACKING
description: In printing presses, paper or other sheet materials used to underlay the plate and/ or blanket (between the cylinder and plate or blanket), to bring the surface of the plate or blanket to the desired height to obtain proper squeeze pressure for printing: can also be adjusted to compensate for minor dimensional changes in the paper in multipass, multicolor printing jobs, but only around the circumference of the cylinder (the print length).

name: PACKAGING
description: The paper and board used for wrapping or packing goods.

name: PACKING LIST
description: A document accompanying shipments listing units shipped (rolls, skids, cartons) including identification numbers and weights.

name: PADDING COMPOUND
description: Also called edge padding glue or adhesive. A liquid adhesive mixture which when brushed or sprayed onto the side of a pile of paper adheres the sheets together along one edge, thus forming a pad.

name: PALLET
description: A pallet is a light, low platform constructed of wood or other suitable material such as solid or laminated paperboard on which various materials (e.g., paper and paperboard) can be loaded and fastened for shipment. A pallet usually consists of two platforms held apart by posts (instead of runners as in a skid) firmly affixed thereto both top and bottom are so arranged that the load can be transported by fork lift truck through entry at either side or end.

name: PAPER
description: Homogenous sheet of felted cellulose fibers, bound together by interweaving and by the use of bonding agents and made in a variety of types. A relatively homogeneous matting of primarily cellulose fibers which are formed from a water suspension on the paper machine wire and bound together by entanglement of the fibers and by bonding agents, and subsequently dried.

name: PAPER MACHINE
description: The machine upon which paper is produced from a suspension of cellulose fibers and other components in water (the furnish) by forming, pressing, drying, surface sizing (in some cases), calendering, and winding on a reel.

name: PAPER MASTER
description: See paper plates.

name: PAPER PLATES
description: A plate for an offset duplicating printing press (offset lithography) made of paper: can be called a "paper master" or "master."

name: PAPERSTOCK
description: Water slurry of various pulp fibers, dyes, additives and chemicals pumped to the paper machine for formation into sheets.

name: PAPETERIE
description: A wide variety of writing papers. used for personal correspondence and greeting cards, with good sizing for pen and ink, with good opacity arid stiffness, and that fold well.

name: PAPYRUS
description: An aquatic plant found in northern Africa. Although papyrus is considered to be the first paper, it's not, in the strict definition of the word, paper (which is a matted web of individual fibers). Rather, early papyrus "paper" was made by peeling the plant, which is constructed like an onion, and placing one layer on top of another. The natural juices acted like glue, bonding the layers and leaving the cellular structure of the plant layers intact.

name: PARCHMENT
description: Animal skins or linings stretched and prepared as writing/painting surfaces. Produces a smooth, buttery surface. Originally a writing surface made from animal skins; today made from cellulose fiber paper by dipping unsized stock in sulfuric acid, to simulate the appearance and feel of genuine parchment; called "vegetable parchment" if made from cellulose fiber paper.

name: PASTE-UP
description: Assembled on one page for photographing the various art, display and text copy for a printing job; another term used is "mechanical."

name: PASTE DRYER/DRIER
description: In ink making, a type of dryer used in inks, usually a combination of dryer compounds; see dryers.

name: PASTER
description: See splice.

name: PATENT COATED
description: Paperboard made and lined with white or colored fibers on a multi-cylinder machine, possessing a high-surface finish suitable for use in making cartons.

name: PERFECT
description: A term used to describe the binding process where the signatures of a book are held together by a flexible adhesive.

name: PERFECT BINDING
description: Binding which uses glue to hold each page in place after the folds along the spine have been cut off. A process of holding pages of a book together with glue (like padding), using no stitching or sewing. The backbones of the books are usually roughened, the adhesive applied, and finished with a wraparound cover.

name: PERFECTING PRESS
description: A printing press that prints on both sides of the page in a single pass. The terms apply to printing both sides of the paper in the same pass on the printing press. Also to print on the back of a sheet already printed on one side. Printing can be on opposite sides, either blanket-to-blanket or sequentially.

name: PERFORATE
description: Punching a series of holes or slits in a line in the paper, to weaken it so tearing will occur easily along that line. Also the making of slits in paper during folding, at the fold, to prevent wrinkles and to allow air to escape.

name: PERFS
description: The actual holes or slots created during perforating.

name: PERMANENCE
description: The ability of a paper to resist change in one or more of its properties during storage and with aging. The resistance to paper to the destructive effects of age; also the "archival" properties of the paper or printed job. A lack of permanence is indicated by a significant loss in strength of the paper or a fade in the color or shades of the paper or printed image. The permanence of paper is chiefly dependent upon the purity of the cellulose used to make the paper, the acidity (see pH) in the paper as a result of manufacture or later contact, and the storage of the paper away from heat, light, and moisture.

name: PH
description: In chemistry, pH is a measure of the concentration of hydrogen ions in a solution, which is a measure of acidity or alkalinity. The pH scale runs from 0 to 14 and each number indicates a ten fold increase. Seven is pH neutral: numbers below 7 indicate increasing acidity, with 1 being the most acid. Numbers above 7 indicate increased alkalinity with 14 being the most alkaline. Paper with a pH below 5 is considered highly acidic. Buffered papers typically have a pH between 8.5 and 9.5. A scientific scale from 0 to 14, measured by instruments, and defining the strength of an acid or alkaline (basic) liquid. From 0 to 7 is acid-, from 7 to 14 is alkaline, while 7 is considered "neutral". i.e., neither acid or alkaline.

name: PHOTOCONDUCTOR
description: See photoreceptor.

name: PHOTORECEPTOR
description: The surface or plate in an electrostatic/ xerographic copier or printer where the image and non-image areas are distinguished. The characteristic of a photoreceptor material is that it holds an electrostatic charge on its surface in the dark, and until the charge is dissipated or erased by exposure to light; when a material has this property with respect to electrostatic charges and light, it is known as a photoconductor. See electrostatic copier/ printer.

name: PH SCALE
description: The potential of the hydrogen ion. A measure of the degree of acidity or alkalinity. A value of 7.0 is neutral on a scale of 0-14. Lower values are acidic, higher are alkaline. Book papers should be neutral or alkaline for longevity.

name: PICA
description: See point (2).

name: PICKING
description: When fibers or fillers are picked from the sheets surface during printing (low surface strength or high ink tacks). The lifting of any material off of, or out of, the paper surface during the printing impression; sometimes due to surface contamination, inadequate surface sizing, inadequate surface strength, or to the ink being too tacky. Generally, the pick will adhere to the blanket and interfere with future impressions;, can appear to be hickeys in the printed surface. For measurement of picking see I.G.T. and wax pick.

name: PIGMENT
description: Insoluble mineral or organic powder used to coat or fill paper. Many pigments are mineral and inorganic compounds used in coating to give smooth surface and opacity. 1) Minerals and other materials used in the manufacture and coating of paper, to provide desired properties. 2) Minerals and other materials, ing colorants, used in the manufacture of printing inks; finely divided solid materials.

name: PILING
description: The accumulation of paper pigments on the printing blanket. The collecting of ink particles upon rollers, blankets and plates, caused either by the inability of an ink vehicle to hold the ink pigment in suspension, or by microscopic pick and/or removal of pigment from the surface of the paper by the ink, and accumulating in the ink on the blanket, usually evidenced in the trailing edge of the image areas, resulting from extra thickness on the press blanket in the image area. If "milking" or "whitening" is severe enough, an accumulation of foreign material can occur in the nonimage areas, also creating an extra thickness there; this is also called non- image area "piling."

name: PINHOLES
description: Imperfections in paper which appear as minute holes upon looking through the sheet: accentuated by lower basis weights.

name: PLAIN PAPER
description: Bond quality uncoated paper used in plain paper copiers.

name: PLANOGRAPHIC PRINTING
description: See offset lithography.

name: PLATE
description: Depending on the printing process, the means by which the image area is separated from the non-image area; the image carrier.

name: PLATE CYLINDER
description: The cylinder on the printing press around which the plate is mounted.

name: PLATE GAP
description: See cylinder gap.

name: PLYBOND
description: Internal bond strength, measure of the resistance of a sheet of paper to delaminate or blister, due to stresses created during printing and drying.

name: PLY
description: The number of pieces of paper that make up a multi-layered, pasted or multi-cylinder-formed paperboard.

name: PMS color
description: An abbreviation for "Pantone Matching System"; an ink color system containing about 500 color swatches, each of which is identified by a color number and a formula for the ink.

name: POINT
description: 1) Refers to the thickness of a sheet of paper in one thousands of an inch. See caliper. 2) A unit of printing type measurement; 0.0 138 of an inch--12 points to the pica--each pica being about 1/6th of an inch, or 72 points to the inch.

name: POOR SPLICE
description: See splice.

name: POOR START
description: Also called bad start; is when there is an obvious difference in the mechanical appearance between paper near the core and the remainder of the side of the roll.

name: POROSITY
description: A measurement of the ability of paper to allow fluids (liquids and gases) to pass through paper and paperboard, which is an important factor in ink penetration. A test which measures the time required for a given amount of air to flow through a sheet of paper; defines how open or tight the sheet of paper is with respect to the passage of air through the sheet.

name: POROUS PRINTING
description: See screen printing and mimeograph printing.

name: POST CONSUMER WASTE
description: Paper products which have served their intended end uses and have now been separated or diverted from solid waste for the purpose of recycling.

name: PORTRAIT MODE
description: A printer (usually driven by a computer) output orientation in which the printed lines run perpendicular to the direction of movement of paper. See landscape mode.

name: PPI
description: Pages per inch.

name: PRE-COLLATED
description: Sheet papers purchased in a predetermined sequence, generally for the sheet printing of business forms. See collated.

name: PRECONSUMER WASTE
description: Manufacturing wastes such as envelope cuttings, bindery trimmings, rejected unused paper, obsolete inventories, and printed paper, which have never reached the consumer.

name: PRESSBOARD
description: Manufactured on a wet machine from sulfate pulp and cotton fiber or a combination of both and finished with a high polish. Thickness ranges from .031 to .250 of an inch. Principal qualities: uniform thickness and density, excellent ply adhesion and good forming and molding properties. Available in a variety of colors.

name: PRESS RUN
description: The quantity specified for any given printing job. Also, the number of impressions made from a printing plate.

name: PRESS SECTION
description: See wet press.

name: PRIMARY COLORS
description: The additive primary colors are the three major wavelengths of light in the visible spectrum: red, green and blue, and are used in applications such as the cathode ray tube of a color television set. The subtractive primary colors are used when dealing with reflected light, such as from a full color printed piece, and are yellow, magenta, and cyan. These are the three colors of ink used in process printing. In paper making, red, yellow, and blue are the primary colors in the dyeing of paper, any two of which can be mixed together to obtain secondary colors and hues (green, orange, and violet).

name: PRINTABILITY
description: Ease with which paper can be printed to high-quality standards with the least amount of spoilage.

name: PRINT CONTRAST
description: A differential measurement of light reflectance between the image and background areas.

name: PRINTING INKS
description: Special coatings applied over specific areas of the paper surface by means of a printing press.

name: PRINTER
description: One who transfers ink onto a substrate in order to recreate a visual image. This is usually done using one of four main printing processes: letterpress, intaglio, planography, or silkscreen.

name: PRINTING
description: The act of producing an image on a page from a machine designed for that purpose, such as a printing press or a computer printer like a laser or ink jet.

name: PRINT ON-DEMAND
description: Refers to the ability to print very small quantities (50-500 copies), quickly and cost-effectively. Traditionally, printing involved an enormous amount of setup time, which resulted in it only being used for large print runs, particularly for color work. Today, the technology has advanced to the point where true on-demand printing is a reality.

name: PROCESS COLOR/INKS
description: A four color reproduction. In four color printing, the process colors are yellow, red (magenta), blue (cyan) and black. Transparent inks used in three-color and four-color printing of full color pictures or drawings; subtractive primary ink colors are yellow, magenta, and cyan. See three and four-color process.

name: PROCESS PRINTING
description: The printing from two or more halftone plates, to produce intermediate shades, hues, and tonal values. See three and four-color process.

name: PROHIBITIVE MATERIALS
description: As published by the Institute of Scrap Recycling Industries, Inc., any materials which by their presence in a packing of paper stock, in excess of the amount allowed, will make the packaging unusable as the grade specified. Additionally, this includes any materials that may be damaging to equipment.

name: PROOFS
description: Samples of copy and/or layout made at various stages of production of a printing job.

name: PSYCHROMETER
description: An instrument for determining the relative humidity of an atmosphere.

name: PUBLISHER
description: Coordinates the production of printed materials such as books, that are sold to the public.

name: PUFFING
description: See fiber puffing.

name: PULP
description: Fibrous material in papermaking produced either mechanically or chemically from fibrous cellulose raw material (wood most common) or Any cellulose plant fiber cleaned and beaten into a wet mixture used to form sheets of paper.

name: PULPER
description: A device composed of a cylindrical vat in which a rotor separates the fibers and suspends them in water.

name: PULPING
description: The act of processing wood (or other plant) to obtain the primary raw material for making paper, usually cellulose fiber. Wood is the most widely used source of fibers for the paper making process. Chemical pulping is generally of the "Kraft" or Sulfate process, the Soda process, or the Sulfite process-see each. Wood pulp can also be obtained for paper making by purely mechanical means ("groundwood") or in combination with chemicals or at elevated temperatures. See semi-chemical and thermomechanical pulps; refiner mechanical pulp (RMP).

name: PVA (POLYVINYLACETATE):
description: An archival white glue that is stronger than gel medium. It mixes well with gloss medium. Transparent even after many coats and remains water soluble. Mixed with gel it becomes water resistant.

name: QUEEN ROLL
description: The second roll from the bottom in a calender stack, usually smaller in diameter than the king roll, but larger than the rest of the rolls above it.

name: QUEUE
description: 1) Waiting in line, or the order by which tasks will be carried out. 2) A set of tasks stored in computer memory for use by a device or machine, in a specified order.

name: QUIRED
description: A ream of paper in which the sheets are folded in half instead of flat.

name: RADIATION CURING
description: Inks have been developed to eliminate solvents (VOCs) when printing by web offset, by having the ability built into the ink to become a hardened image; 100% of the ink composition becomes hardened into the dried ink film. Generally the hardening reaction is triggered by either exposure to Ultra Violet radiation (UV) or to an Electron Beam (EB). The same types of materials and principles have been applied to what is called 100% solids coating.

name: RAG
description: Formerly the principal raw material used in the making process; often meaning cotton rags. Rag content describes the amount of cotton fiber relative to the total amount of material used in the pulp. "Rag content" is not widely used (or is a misnomer) today as more and more high quality paper is made not from rag but from linters.

name: RAG CONTENT PAPER
description: See cotton fiber paper.

name: RAGGED
description: Can be "ragged left" or "ragged right"; line and type that has been "justified" to the right or left only, with the opposite side being left uneven or "ragged."

name: RATTLE
description: The crisp, crackling sound produced by shaking or crumpling a sheet of paper to indicate its rigidity or stiffness.

name: RAW STOCK
description: The paper to which coating is applied.

name: REAM
description: 500 sheets of paper. Sheet count of paper (500 sheets for most fine papers); see basis weight.

name: REAM WEIGHT
description: The weight of one ream of paper, either actual or nominal. The amount that one ream of a particular paper weighs.

name: RECESSED PRINTING
description: See gravure printing and engraving.

name: RECLAIMED FIBER
description: Recovered fiber in a pure or usable form obtained from refuse matter.

name: RECOVERY SYSTEM
description: System in a pulp mill where black liquor is burned and inorganic chemicals are recovered and circulated in the process.

name: RECYCLABLE SYMBOL
description: Symbol used to indicate that the paper may be used in the recycling process.

name: RECYCLE
description: To reuse, or to use over and over; see de-inking.

name: RECYCLED CONTENT PAPER
description: A paper product containing some, but consisting of less than 100% recovered fibers.

name: RECYCLED FIBER
description: Cellulose fiber reclaimed from waste material and reused, sometimes with a minor portion of virgin material, to produce new paper.

name: RECYCLED PAPER
description: EPA defines this as paper including postconsumer and preconsumer wastes, which are made from at least 50% waste paper.

name: RECYCLED SYMBOL
description: Symbol used to indicate that the paper is made from recycled fibers. The percentage of paper of which the fibrous composition contains recovered or recycled cellulose fibers (RCF).

name: REDUCERS
description: Materials that are added to inks to reduce either ink tack or viscosity.

name: REEL
description: The untrimmed roll of paper that is wound on the full-width shaft at the paper machine dry end. A roll of paper.

name: REFERENCE BOOKS
description: The category of books which are produced for reference such as encyclopedias, dictionaries, law books, etc.

name: REFINER MACHANICAL PULP (RMP)
description: Pulp made by processing untreated wood chips in mechanical atmospheric refiners. mechanical pulp obtained by first chipping the wood, then separating the cellulose fibers by mechanical rotary refiners. See groundwood.

name: REFINING
description: The process of increasing the surface area of cellulose fibers to multiply the number of contact points between them to facilitate their intertwining. Imparts such characteristics as increased capacity to absorb water and improved sheet formation. See cellulose fibers and furnish, the process of preparing cellulose fibers for the making of paper, by mechanical action, whereby the individual fibers are separated from each other, flattened, and roughened (see fibrillation) to various degrees, to obtain the desired final paper properties. The flattening action was earlier referred to as "beating" the fibers, and was accomplished in equipment called "beaters," in a batch process. Today, most refining is continuous, by means of rotating, close clearance steel bars (plates); disk refiners are the more modern equipment, used today.

name: REFLECTANCE
description: The percent of incident light reflected from an image area, where zero percent reflectance is black and 100 percent is white; see image density.

name: REFRACTIVE
description: Ability to bend light from a straight course. Materials differ in refractivity, which is measured as "refractive index." The refractive index of materials used in the furnish to make paper, will to a great extent determine the differences in opacity of various types of paper, at equivalent basis weights.

name: REGISTER
description: The correct position of printing on paper and the correct position of each color in multi-color printing. 1) Paper: a type of bond paper for multi-ply form use; i.e. register bond. 2) Printing: when a design or form is printed in parts or steps, as in multiple colors, it is essential that all parts or inks down match exactly. When they do, they are "in register" or in registration; otherwise, they are "out of register"; see hairline and commercial register.

name: REGISTER MARKS
description: Fine lines crossing at right angles and placed on original copy before color separation. Used for positioning images, registering colors, accurate cutting, etc.

name: RELATIVE HUMIDITY (RH)
description: The amount of water vapor present in the air as compared to the maximum potential amount. Percent of moisture in the air, relative to the amount of moisture it can hold without precipitation, at any given temperature measured with a psychrometer; humidity or absolute humidity is a measure of the grains of moisture per unit volume of air.

name: RELEASE PAPER
description: Papers designed to be stripped away or released from another surface.

name: RELIEF PRINTING
description: See letterpress and flexographic printing.

name: REMAKE
description: An order entered to supplement an item which was manufactured at insufficient quantity.

name: REPLACEMENT ORDER
description: Order entered to replace paper shipped which has proven inferior or damaged.

name: REPROGRAPHY
description: Copying and duplicating.

name: RESERVATION
description: Systematic allocation of paper machine capacity by a manufacturer on a customer-by-customer basis according to historical buying patterns. This process typically enacted during tight market conditions, ensures the manufacturer will be able to keep integrity within the order scheduling process while providing regular product availability to standard customers.

name: RESIN
description: The vegetable excretion or exudation that results in an amorphous, lustrous-appearing, solid organic substance that is soluble in organic solvents.

name: RETENTION
description: The amount of a loading or additive added to the stock that is retained in the final sheet of paper.

name: RETENTION AIDS
description: Materials added to the furnish of a paper machine, to help in keeping the fine particles of the furnish, with and in the formed wet mat of paper on the wire; this is to reduce losses and to retain the fines for the properties they can impart to the finished sheet of paper.

name: REVERSE EMBOSSING
description: A printing defect in which the stresses created in the separation of the paper from the blanket stretches the paper and actually raises the printed surface in the image areas (and generally creates a depression on the back), sufficient to distort the sheet of paper and even prevent its laying flat.

name: REVERSE SEQUENCE
description: In a multi-ply business form that is to be run once through the printing press or offset duplicator, the sequence (order) of the plies will normally be reversed by running once through the press. After printing, the desired sequence is the usable (crash or straight sequence. See crash sequence). Before printing the sequence is called "reverse" and is a "mirror" of the final desired sequence.

name: REWINDER
description: A machine which takes rolls from the reel of the paper machine, the coater, or other winder, and slits and/or rewinds into smaller rolls.

name: RH
description: See relative humidity.

name: RIDGE
description: A ring around the circumference of a roll or an area in a skid of paper in the machine direction that is harder or higher than an adjacent area; also called hard spot.

name: RIGHT SIDE OF PAPER
description: The felt side of a sheet. Also, the side on which the watermark, if any, may be read.

name: RMP
description: See refiner mechanical pulp.

name: ROLL CROWN
description: The surface curvature shape or diameter profile of wide width rolls under high pressure (pli) to compensate for deflection and obtain a level nip or pressure across the full width.

name: ROLL CURL
description: Also called wrap curl. See simple curl.

name: ROLL STAND
description: Frame and mechanism for supporting a roll of paper as it unwinds and feeds into a coater, printing press, or other converting operation.

name: ROPE
description: Also called "corrugation"; bands of relatively uniform width which occur in the machine direction, around the roll of paper, with uniform diagonal marks present in the band. These bands result from wide areas in the cross direction, of caliper differences, resulting in a roll attempting to wind to two different diameters; if tightness of wind is great enough or the caliper differences are accentuated as in large roll diameters, the rope or corrugation can become "set" and be evidenced in the subsequent pile of sheet paper.

name: ROSETTE PATTERN
description: When preparing color separations for printing, the screen angles are rotated for each process color ink. A symmetrical (but non-objectionable) "rosette" dot pattern can result, which the eye can merge into smooth color gradations. However, incorrect screening angles or the shifting of the paper during printing can result in objectionable patterns. See moir' patterns.

name: ROSIN
description: Material made up of a suspension and used for internal sizing of paper and paperboard. A natural resin obtained from pine trees, and when suitably modified, is used as an internal sizing agent to impart waterproofness to paper; used in acid sizing of paper. See alum.

name: ROTARY PRESS
description: A printing press that carries curved plates on a cylinder (or the plate is the surface of the cylinder), as opposed to an older style flatbed press, using flat plates and type. All elements of the press are cylindrical in shape.

name: ROTOGRAVURE
description: Web gravure printing using rotary equipment. See gravure printing.

name: ROUGH FRONT BOOK
description: A book with untrimmed pages along its front.

name: RUBINE
description: A pigment somewhat redder than true magenta.

name: RUNNABILITY
description: Paper properties that affect the ability of the paper to run on the printing press. Paper properties that effect the ability of the paper to run on coating, converting, or printing equipment.

name: RUNNING HEAD
description: A title at the top of a page that appears on all pages of a book or chapter in a book.

name: SADDLE STITCHING/WIRE
description: In binding, staples (formed from a continuous wire) driven through the back fold of a booklet, clinched in the middle, and enabling the booklet to open out flat. The same type of binding can be accomplished with a stapler, using pre-formed staples.

name: SAFETY PAPER
description: Used mainly as bank checks and other legal documents. Safety paper is specially treated to prevent erasure, alteration or duplication of any writing or printing on its surface. A treated paper which when writing or printing on the paper is altered, the alteration attempt will leave a noticeable smudge, discoloration, or other evidence of change, this type of paper might be used for making checks or other documents to discourage such alterations.

name: SALES BOOK
description: Set of forms bound into a book, usually for ease of writing.

name: SATIN FINISH
description: A smooth, delicately embossed finished paper with sheen. Also called silk. A finish lacking gloss, generally intermediate to a matte finish and a dull finish. See gloss.

name: SAVE-ALL
description: A device on the paper machine which screens paper fibers from water, to save pulp which might otherwise be lost to the sewer.

name: SCALE
description: Foreign materials from the paper making or converting operations deposited on the web after it is formed, and can be starch or coating materials broken loose from the sheet, and redeposited. Scale in the printing operation can adhere to the blanket and transfer to the plate causing defects in the printed piece. The terms calendar scale and coating scale are often used in relation to this defect, implying where in the paper making process the scale was deposited on the sheet.

name: SCANNING
description: In printing plate preparation, an electronic method, based on point by point scanning of color separations and tonal gradations under computer control.

name: SCORING
description: To impress paper with a rule for the purpose of making folding easier. The process and the resulting line mechanically impressed into a heavy sheet of paper or board, to pre-stress the fold line and facilitate folding or improve the appearance of the fold. Most effectively done with the grain of the paper, and is absolutely necessary with heavier basis weight paper.

name: SCRAP IN ROLL
description: Trim or scrap paper wound into the roll of paper. The scrap may or may not be protruding from the ends of the roll.

name: SCREEN ANGLES
description: In color reproduction, the halftone screens are rotated with relation to one another, to avoid undesirable moir' patterns. The angles usually used are black 45 degrees, magenta 75 degrees, yellow 90 degrees, and cyan 105 degrees.

name: SCREEN PRINTING
description: A form of porous printing. The process by which the image area is created by forcing ink through a "screen" or mesh, created by blocking off all areas in the "screen" where no image is to be formed; an example would be silk screen printing of T-shirts. Mimeograph printing is also another form of porous (screen) printing.

name: SCREEN RULINGS
description: The number of lines or dots per inch on a halftone screen. See screens.

name: SCREENINGS
description: Rejected materials, such as knots, shives and large bark particles, from the screening operations of pulp suspensions in a pulp mill.

name: SCREENS
description: Halftone illustrations. The ruling (usually expressed as lines per inch, i.e., 120 lpi, 133 lpi, 150 lpi) used to determine the dots per unit area in developing tonal values in the printed piece. Up to the point of "dot gain," the higher the screen, the finer the lines per inch, the greater the fineness of detail in the printed piece. See stochastic screening.

name: SCUFFING
description: The disrupted appearance of an ink film as a result of abrasion to either the wet or dry ink film.

name: SCUMMING
description: A term describing the condition resulting when any non-image area of the plate tends to take ink (any cause); when this starts to occur in offset lithography, it is said that the plate is "catching up"; can also be called toning.

name: SEAM MARK
description: Is a defect in the web, normally running at approximate right angles to the machine direction and is seen as a light streak when viewed by transmitted light. Point of origin is usually an article of machine clothing, a wire or a felt, that is seamed. The distance from one defect to the other is a clue as to the origin of the mark.

name: SECONDARY FIBER
description: Any type of paper and paperboard fiber obtained from wastepaper and other used reclaimable fiber sources. A term used for wastepaper. Recycled into the paper making process.

name: SECONDARY PULP
description: Lower-quality pulp made from waste paper and not directly from wood.

name: SELF COVER
description: Booklet cover that matches the inside pages. Carbonless paper, where the colorless dyes and color developers are contained in the sheet or in the coating on one side of the sheet, and color is developed in sitsu (not a transfer of chemicals as in a mated system), by the action of an impact or writing instrument to release the colorless dyes.

name: SEMI-CHEMICAL PULP
description: A pulp produced by a mild chemical treatment followed by a mechanical defiberizing operation. A pulping process, not widely used in Fine Papers, that uses chemicals to assist a mechanical pulping process, and gives a pulp similar to chemical pulp.

name: SEPARATION
description: The act of separating (dividing) the colors of an original into its component colors (yellow, magenta, cyan, black, and any spot colors); each record or negative is used for the production of a single color printing plate.

name: SEQUENCE
description: See color sequence.

name: SET
description: Inks are said to be "set" when the ink film on a printed piece is immobile, though not fully dry, and can be handled without smudging/smearing.

name: SEWED
description: The actual sewing through all the pages of a book which is to be case bound.

name: SHADOW MARKS
description: 1) Also couch marks; defects which appear as a regular pattern, always when viewed by transmitted light and sometimes when viewed by direct light. Cause is usually some non-uniform water removal from the sheet of paper in the wet end of the paper machine, and takes the pattern of the equipment removing the water (such as a drilled hole suction couch roll). 2) Can also be intentional watermark patterning, using the dandy roll. See dandy roll.

name: SET-OFF
description: Transferring or smearing of ink from freshly-printed sheets of paper to another surface (also called off-set). The transfer of ink from a printed sheet to another sheet in contact with it at the delivery end of a printing press and/ or during subsequent bindery operations.

name: SHEET
description: Flat piece of any type of pulp, paper and paperboard that has a variety of characteristics, sizes and finishes.

name: SHEET FED
description: Presses that print sheets instead of rolls. A printing process, where the paper is processed as sheets, as opposed to processing from a web (roll/ribbon). Ink-drying mechanisms can differ between the sheet-fed and web-fed offset lithography printing processes.

name: SHEFFIELD SMOOTHNESS
description: The smoothness of paper as measured by the Sheffield paper smoothness gauge, expressed as the rate of airflow between the measuring surface and the paper surface under specified conditions.

name: SHIVES
description: Uncooked wood particles which show up in the finished sheet; in groundwood pulps. bundles of fibers resulting from less than mechanical separation.

name: SHORT INK
description: See length.

name: SHORT RUN
description: A press run which will produce a small quantity of books.

name: SHOW-THROUGH
description: Visibility of printing on the reverse side of the paper. Also called strikethrough; the undesirable condition where the printing on the reverse side can be seen through the sheet under normal lighting. See opacity.

name: SHRUNKEN EDGES
description: See tight edges.

name: SIDE GUIDE
description: A guide on sheet fed equipment to position the sheet sideways for the operation. On web fed equipment, this is called an edge guide.

name: SIGNATURE
description: A section of a book, folded ready for binding with other sections. "Sigs" usually range from 16-32 pages but could be as low as 4 and as high as 64. A folded sheet of printed paper usually a section of a book or magazine (or newspaper), ordinarily obtained by the folding of a single sheet into 4, 8, 16, or more pages. The term signature can also be applied to a printed flat sheet that is to be later folded into a multi-page document.

name: SILK SCREEN PRINTING
description: A form of porous printing. Originally, the porous material for making the screen was a silk fabric, thus the name. See screen printing.

name: SILIVICHEMICALS
description: Chemical byproducts of the wood-pulping process and other chemicals derived from wood.

name: SIMPLE CURL
description: 1) structural curl is the bending of a sheet of paper around the grain direction. and is generally caused by differential moisture changes (cellulose fiber diameter changes) from one side of the sheet versus the other. 2) Wrap curl is the result of the sheet becoming "set" when wrapped around a core. It is always curl or bending perpendicular to the grain.

name: SIZE
description: Non-fibrous materials used in papermaking to control the absorbency of paper. Rosin, starch, alum and gelatins are most commonly used. A water resisting material which is added to paper. See sizing.

name: SIZE PRESS
description: Section of paper machine where surface treatments are applied to the sheet of paper to give it special qualities. Normally a pair of rolls toward the end of the dryer train between which the dry or partially dry web is passed, and into the nip of which a liquid, usually starch, is applied to impart strength to the sheet. The part of the paper machine that applies a surface size or treatment to the web of paper. See surface sizing.

name: SIZING
description: The process by which gelatin rosin, starch or other synthetic substance is added to paper to provide resistance to the absorption of moisture or eliminating ink feathering and bleed through. Sizing added to the beater or vat of pulp is known as internal sizing. After a sheet is formed, it may be either surface sized (painted or brushed on the surface), or tub sized (immersed in a bath). A treatment to improve the resistance to a liquid (particularly water) or vapor; surface or internal sizing. Sizing or waterproofness is generally measured as the time required for a water-based fluid or ink to penetrate from one surface of paper to the other, through the sheet. See size press, acid sizing or alkaline sizing.

name: SKID
description: A platform (usually 8 inches or more in height) which is supported by runners extending lengthwise of the skid. It is generally higher than a pallet and since it has no bottom platform, is not generally stacked. A skid is moved by means of a platform truck.

name: SKINNING
description: The formation of a dried layer on the surface of a fluid such as an ink or coating (like a paint), after a period of standing.

name: SLACK SIZED
description: Refers to paper which has very little or no sizing, to resist moisture penetration; opposite of hard sized.

name: SLICE
description: The opening in the headbox of the paper machine, where the furnish is uniformly forced out onto the wire for the web of paper to be formed.

name: SLIME
description: Bacterial micro-organisms growing in the wet end of the paper machine system, that if left uncontrolled, can break loose and become a part of the paper web-usually a "slime" hole results. Normally controlled by slimicides or biocides, added to the wet end of the paper machine.

name: SLIMICIDES
description: See slime.

name: SLIP
description: High concentration slurry (even semi- solid) of paper making or coating pigment in water.

name: SLIPPED ROLL
description: An unevenly wound roll which is usually the result of loose winding; see telescoped roll.

name: SLITTER
description: A sharp knife (generally a sharp disc) which cuts paper into predetermined widths; if not properly set or maintained can give a poor, non-uniform, or dusty cut.

name: SLITTER DUST
